events.name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Program for Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder
events.description:
Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) is a heterogeneous psychiatric disorder in which individuals avoid certain foods or food categories, limiting their diet in terms of variety and/or restrict their intake in terms of quantity. One of the most common reasons for avoidance or restriction in ARFID is increased sensitivity to the sensory properties of food (e.g., taste, texture, appearance, smell). Individuals with ARFID may also avoid or restrict foods due to fears of unwanted outcomes, such as choking, vomiting, or gastrointestinal pain. Often, these individuals have experienced trauma related to food and begin to avoid certain foods to protect against another negative experience. In ARFID, a lack of interest in food or eating is also common, and individuals may maintain a limited diet in terms of quantity. Those with a lack of interest often describe eating as a chore, which manifests as a low appetite.

Psychological therapies are at the forefront of ARFID treatment. A cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT-AR) was developed for ARFID. This therapy includes three optional modules that the therapist can apply based on the patient‚Äôs primary maintaining mechanism. It can be delivered in an individual or family-supported format, depending on the patient‚Äôs age, and lasts 20-30 sessions depending on the severity of the eating disorder. This program will address ARFID treatment from a psychotherapeutic perspective.

This program consists of 4 sessions, totaling 8 hours.

events.name: Temperament Training, Temperament-Based Communication Skills, Pathology and Preventive Mental Health
events.description:
Purpose:
To better understand and know ourselves, our families, colleagues, and those around us.
To assess potential pathologies based on the temperaments of clients.
To develop skills to protect our mental health against anger and stress.
To recognize the attitudes and behaviors of our managers and colleagues at school and work.
To identify the personality traits that form the learning styles of our personnel, understand their limitations and potentials, and respond appropriately.

Scope:
After learning the temperament approach, temperament test usage will be studied. Then, potential pathology and preventive work will be evaluated. Students will be provided with a temperament test and presentation.

events.name: Solution-Focused Brief Therapy for Children and Schools
events.description:
Solution-focused brief therapy consists of a set of special techniques that therapists and counselors can use during the counseling process. This certification program aims to teach how to apply this set of techniques to children.

These techniques help the client focus on their strengths and the times when the problem does not occur and are supported by various tasks and exercises. With a ‚Äúproblem occurs, solution found‚Äù perspective, change is initiated by encouraging the client to try ways they have never attempted before, recall periods when the problem was manageable, and tap into their positive sides. Change is achieved, and developmental contributions are made to sustain this change. The focus is on Here and Now, not the past or future. By keeping workable solutions and changing ineffective ones, continuity of change is ensured. This certification program aims to equip professionals working with children and in school settings with the skills to apply Solution-Focused Brief Therapy techniques.

Program Content

History and development of solution-focused brief therapy
Basic principles of solution-focused brief therapy and its areas of use in therapy
Building a therapeutic relationship with child clients,
Obtaining a problem description and setting goals with the child client and family.
Revealing exceptional situations and grading the problem
Directing the client towards solutions with miracle questions
Examples of solution-focused counseling approach questions through role plays
Applying solution-focused brief therapy techniques to child clients
